text: For many visitors, desert scenery exhibits a striking beauty; to others, the terrain seems bleak.
Desert landscapes and their development provide another excellent example of the strong link between climate and geology.
Their profiles are not softened by a continuous carpet of soil and abundant plant life.

Except for special types of cut stone used for building and monuments, transportation costs greatly limit the distance most building materials can be profitably moved.
Cement and aggregate go into the making of concrete, a material that is essential to practically all construction.
Aggregate gives concrete its strength and volume, and cement binds the mixture into a rock-hard substance.
Besides aggregate, other important building materials include gypsum for plaster and wallboard, clay for tile and bricks, and limestone and shale, which combine to form cement.
Aggregate is produced commercially in every state and is used in nearly all building construction and in most public works projects.
Building an average six-room house requires 90 tons of aggregate.
Building just 2 kilometers of fourlane highway requires more than 85 thousand tons of aggregate.
The United States produces nearly 2 billion tons of aggregate per year, which represents about one-half of the country’s entire nonenergy mining volume.
Because most building materials are widely distributed and present in almost unlimited quantities, they have little intrinsic value.
Since their per-ton value compared with the values of metals and industrial minerals is low, mining and quarrying operations are usually undertaken to satisfy local needs.
Their economic worth comes only after the materials are removed from the ground and processed.
From the standpoint of quantity and value, aggregate is a very important building material.
Natural aggregate consists of crushed stone, sand, and gravel.

Perhaps the easiest type of bond to visualize is the ionic bond, in which one atom gives up one or more valence electrons to another atom to form ions—positively and negatively charged atoms.
Chlorine, on the other hand, gains one electron and becomes a negatively charged chloride ion.
In other words, the two electrons are shared by both hydrogen atoms and are attracted simultaneously by the positive in the solid ionic compound sodium chloride (NaCl), table salt.

Imagine two hydrogen atoms (each with one proton and one electron) approaching one another, as shown in Once they meet, the electron configuration will change so that both electrons will primarily occupy the space between the atoms.
The strong attractive force that holds two hydrogen atoms together results from a covalent bond, a chemical bond formed by the sharing of one or more valence electrons between a pair of atoms.

Oppositely charged ions are strongly attracted to one another and join to form ionic Consider the ionic bonding that occurs between sodium (Na) and chlorine (Cl) to produce the solid ionic compound sodium chloride—the mineral halite atom gives up its single valence electron to chlorine and, as a result, becomes a positively charged sodium ion.
This arrangement maximizes the attraction between ions with opposite charges while minimizing the repulsion between ions with identical charges.
Notice that salt consists of alternating sodium and chlorine ions, positioned in such a manner that each positive ion is attracted to and surrounded on all sides by negative ions and vice versa.
Sometimes the forces that hold atoms together cannot be understood on the basis of the attraction of oppositely charged ions.
Thus, an ionic bond is the attraction of oppositely charged ions to one another, and it produces an electrically neutral ionic compound.
Thus, ionic compounds consist of an orderly arrangement of oppositely charged ions assembled in a definite ratio that provides overall electrical neutrality.

Minerals can also precipitate from slowly moving groundwater filling in fractures and voids in rocks and sediments.
Geodes sometimes contain spectacular crystals of quartz, calcite, or other less common minerals.
Geodes like this one form when silica dissolved in groundwater precipitates to form quartz crystals that grow within cavities in rocks.
One interesting example, called a geode, is a somewhat spherically shaped object with inwardprojecting crystals that were gradually deposited by groundwater .
Once saturation is reached, the ions begin to bond, forming crystalline solids (called salts) that precipitate from (settle out of) the solution.
Perhaps the most familiar way in which minerals grow is from an aqueous (water) solution containing dissolved material matter (ions).
Two factors—a drop in temperature and water lost through evaporation—cause the solution to become closer to reaching saturation.
Worldwide, extensive evaporite deposits, some exceeding hundreds of meters in thickness, provide evidence of ancient seas that have long since evaporated (see page 100).
The Great Salt Lake in Utah and Bolivia’s great salt flat, Salar de Uyuni, provide good examples of this process at work .
As long as the solution is not saturated, the motion of the dissolved ions keeps them from joining together.

Because they are located in arid regions with high evaporation rates, these water bodies regularly precipitate the minerals halite, sylvite, and gypsum, as well as other soluble salts, called evaporite deposits.

Minerals tend to have one common crystal shape, but a few, such as the pyrite samples shown in have two or more characteristic crystal shapes.
Mineralogists use the term crystal shape, or habit, to refer to the common or characteristic shape of individual crystals or aggregates of crystals.
For example, magnetite crystals sometimes occur as octahedrons, garnets often form dodecahedrons, and halite and fluorite crystals tend to grow as cubes or near-cubes.
Metallic minerals generally have a dense, dark streak, whereas minerals with nonmetallic luster typically have a light-colored streak.
Although the color of a mineral is not always helpful in identification, the streak, which is the color of the powdered mineral, can be very useful.

Some minerals tend to grow equally in all three dimensions, whereas others tend to be elongated in one direction or flattened minerals have crystals that exhibit regular polygons that are helpful in their identification.
Streak can also help distinguish between minerals with metallic luster and those with nonmetallic luster.
Quartz, for example, is harder than a porcelain streak plate and therefore leaves no streak.)

Of the many optical properties of minerals, their luster, their ability to transmit light, their color, and their streak are most frequently used for mineral identification.

Minerals have definite crystalline structures and chemical compositions that give them unique sets of physical and chemical properties shared by all specimens of that mineral, regardless of when or where they formed.
For example, two samples of the mineral quartz will be equally hard and equally dense, and they will break in a similar manner.
Because so few minerals share this property, a salty taste is considered a diagnostic property of halite.
Some mineral properties, called diagnostic properties, are particularly useful in identifying an unknown mineral.

However, the physical properties of individual samples may vary within specific limits due to ionic substitutions, inclusions of foreign elements (impurities), and defects in the crystalline structure.
These properties are referred to as ambiguous properties.
Other properties of certain minerals vary among different specimens of the same mineral.
The mineral halite, for example has a salty taste.

Most pegmatites are granitic in composition and consist of unusually large crystals of quartz, feldspar, and muscovite.
Most pegmatites are located within large igneous masses or as dikes or veins that cut into the host rock surrounding the magma chamber .
Crystallization in a fluid-rich environment, where ion migration is enhanced, results in the formation of crystals several centimeters, or even a few meters, in length.
They are useful catalysts in petroleum refining and are used to manufacture strong magnets for turbines and rechargeable batteries for cell phones and computers.

Further, because water and other volatile substances do not crystallize along with the bulk of the magma body, these fluids make up a high percentage of the melt during the final phase of solidification.
The resulting rocks, called pegmatites, are composed of these unusually large crystals.
Pegmatite Deposits Magmatic differentiation is important in the late stages of the magmatic process.
Thus, in addition to the common silicates, some pegmatites include semiprecious gems such as beryl, topaz, and tourmaline.
This is particularly true of granitic magmas, in which the residual melt can become enriched in rare elements and heavy metals.
*The rare earths are a group of 15 elements (atomic numbers 57 through 71) that possess similar properties.
Further, pegmatites often contain some of the least abundant elements.

One group of feldspar minerals contains potassium ions in its structure and is therefore referred to as potassium feldspar.
Striations are found on some cleavage planes of plagioclase feldspar but are not present on potassium feldspar .
Potassium feldspar is usually light cream, salmon pink, or occasionally blue-green in color.
As a component in igneous rocks, feldspar crystals can be identified by their rectangular shape and rather smooth, shiny faces .
The plagioclase feldspars, on the other hand, range in color from white to medium gray.
The other group, called plagioclase feldspar, contains both sodium and calcium ions that freely substitute for one another, depending on the environment during crystallization.
They have two planes of cleavage meeting at or near 90-degree angles, are relatively hard (6 on the Mohs scale), and have a luster that ranges from glassy to pearly.
The only way to distinguish the feldspars physically is to look for a multitude of fine parallel lines, called striations.
However, color should not be used to distinguish these groups.
Despite these differences, all feldspar minerals have similar physical properties.
(Orthoclase and microcline are common members of the potassium feldspar group.)
Two different feldspar structures exist.

During this time of intense heating, Earth became hot enough that elements including iron and nickel began to melt.

Perhaps the easiest type of bond to visualize is the ionic bond, in which one atom gives up one or more valence electrons to another atom to form ions—positively and negatively charged atoms.
The strong attractive force that holds two hydrogen atoms together results from a covalent bond, a chemical bond formed by the sharing of one or more valence electrons between a pair of atoms.
Chlorine, on the other hand, gains one electron and becomes a negatively charged chloride ion.

Oppositely charged ions are strongly attracted to one another and join to form ionic Consider the ionic bonding that occurs between sodium (Na) and chlorine (Cl) to produce the solid ionic compound sodium chloride—the mineral halite atom gives up its single valence electron to chlorine and, as a result, becomes a positively charged sodium ion.
In other words, the two electrons are shared by both hydrogen atoms and are attracted simultaneously by the positive in the solid ionic compound sodium chloride (NaCl), table salt.
Notice that salt consists of alternating sodium and chlorine ions, positioned in such a manner that each positive ion is attracted to and surrounded on all sides by negative ions and vice versa.

Imagine two hydrogen atoms (each with one proton and one electron) approaching one another, as shown in Once they meet, the electron configuration will change so that both electrons will primarily occupy the space between the atoms.
This arrangement maximizes the attraction between ions with opposite charges while minimizing the repulsion between ions with identical charges.
Thus, an ionic bond is the attraction of oppositely charged ions to one another, and it produces an electrically neutral ionic compound.
Sometimes the forces that hold atoms together cannot be understood on the basis of the attraction of oppositely charged ions.
Thus, ionic compounds consist of an orderly arrangement of oppositely charged ions assembled in a definite ratio that provides overall electrical neutrality.

The most common varieties of quartz are milky (white), smoky (gray), rose (pink), amethyst (purple), citrine (yellow to brown), and rock crystal (clear) .
However, like most other clear minerals, quartz is often colored by inclusions of various ions (impurities) and forms without developing good crystal faces.
When pure, quartz is clear and, if allowed to grow without interference, will develop hexagonal crystals with pyramid-shaped ends.
Because quartz ion (Si41), no other positive ions are needed to attain In quartz, a three-dimensional framework is developed through the complete sharing of oxygen by adjacent silicon atoms.
When broken, quartz generally exhibits conchoidal fracture.
Consequently, quartz is hard, resists weathering, and does not have cleavage.
Thus, all the bonds in quartz are of the strong silicon–oxygen type.
As such, the term silica is applied to quartz.

One group of feldspar minerals contains potassium ions in its structure and is therefore referred to as potassium feldspar.
Striations are found on some cleavage planes of plagioclase feldspar but are not present on potassium feldspar .
Potassium feldspar is usually light cream, salmon pink, or occasionally blue-green in color.
As a component in igneous rocks, feldspar crystals can be identified by their rectangular shape and rather smooth, shiny faces .
The other group, called plagioclase feldspar, contains both sodium and calcium ions that freely substitute for one another, depending on the environment during crystallization.
The only way to distinguish the feldspars physically is to look for a multitude of fine parallel lines, called striations.
The plagioclase feldspars, on the other hand, range in color from white to medium gray.
They have two planes of cleavage meeting at or near 90-degree angles, are relatively hard (6 on the Mohs scale), and have a luster that ranges from glassy to pearly.
However, color should not be used to distinguish these groups.
Despite these differences, all feldspar minerals have similar physical properties.
(Orthoclase and microcline are common members of the potassium feldspar group.)
Two different feldspar structures exist.

Minerals tend to have one common crystal shape, but a few, such as the pyrite samples shown in have two or more characteristic crystal shapes.
Mineralogists use the term crystal shape, or habit, to refer to the common or characteristic shape of individual crystals or aggregates of crystals.
Metallic minerals generally have a dense, dark streak, whereas minerals with nonmetallic luster typically have a light-colored streak.
Although the color of a mineral is not always helpful in identification, the streak, which is the color of the powdered mineral, can be very useful.
For example, magnetite crystals sometimes occur as octahedrons, garnets often form dodecahedrons, and halite and fluorite crystals tend to grow as cubes or near-cubes.

Some minerals tend to grow equally in all three dimensions, whereas others tend to be elongated in one direction or flattened minerals have crystals that exhibit regular polygons that are helpful in their identification.
Streak can also help distinguish between minerals with metallic luster and those with nonmetallic luster.

Using this technique, zones of intensity were identified, with the zone of highest intensity located near the center of maximum ground shaking and often (but not always) the earthquake epicenter.

To more accurately compare earthquakes around the globe, scientists searched for a way to describe the energy released by earthquakes that did not rely on factors such as building practices, which vary considerably from one part of the world to another.
By systematically mapping effects of the earthquake, a measure of the intensity of ground shaking was established.
Until the mid-1800s, historical records provided the only accounts of the severity of earthquake shaking and destruction.

In contrast to granite, which is widely distributed as large intrusive masses, rhyolite deposits are less common and generally less voluminous.
Rhyolite is fine-grained and frequently contains glass fragments and voids, indicating that it cooled rapidly in a surface, or near-surface, environment.

Therefore, gneiss represents the highest-grade metamorphic rock in the sequence of shale, slate, phyllite, schist, and gneiss.
Like schists, gneisses may also include large crystals of accessory minerals such as garnet.
Some gneisses will split along the layers of platy minerals, but most break in an irregular fashion.
Recall that during high-grade metamorphism, the light and dark components separate, giving gneisses their characteristic banded or layered appearance.
Gneiss Gneiss is the term applied to medium- to coarse-grained banded metamorphic rocks in which granular and elongated (as opposed to platy) minerals predominate.
Thus, most gneisses consist of alternating bands of white or reddish feldspar-rich zones and layers of dark ferromagnesian minerals .
For example, an amphibole-rich rock that exhibits a gneissic texture is called amphibolite.
These banded gneisses often exhibit evidence of deformation, including folds and sometimes Gneisses having a felsic composition may be derived from granite or its fine-grained equivalent, rhyolite.
Gneisses made up primarily of dark minerals also occur.
However, most gneisses are generated through highgrade metamorphism of shale.
Most gneisses also contain lesser amounts of biotite, muscovite, and amphibole.
The most common minerals in gneiss are quartz, potassium feldspar, and plagioclase feldspar.

Recall from Bowen’s reaction series that rocks with a granitic composition are composed of minerals with the lowest melting (crystallization) temperatures—namely, quartz and potassium feldspar .
Also note that as we move up Bowen’s reaction series, the minerals have progressively higher melting temperatures and that olivine, which is found at the top, has the highest melting point.

When a rock undergoes partial melting, it will form a melt that is enriched in ions from minerals with the lowest melting temperatures, while the unmelted portion is composed of minerals with higher melting temperatures .
Recall that igneous rocks are composed of a mixture of minerals and, therefore, tend to melt over the lowest melting temperatures are the first to melt.

In general, partial melting of ultramafic rocks tends to yield mafic (basaltic) magmas, partial melting of mafic rocks generally yields intermediate (andesitic) magmas, and partial melting of intermediate rocks can generate felsic (granitic) magmas.
If melting continues, minerals with higher melting points begin to melt, and the composition of the melt steadily approaches the overall composition of the rock from which it was derived.
Separation of these two fractions yields a melt with a chemical composition that is richer in silica and nearer the felsic (granitic) end of the spectrum than the rock from which it formed.
The incomplete melting of rocks is known as partial melting, a process that produces most magma.
Most often, however, melting is not complete.
